full_title_en: Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score with CRP (ASDAS-CRP)
medium_description_en: Stratifies severity of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) using clinical and laboratory data, specifically CRP.

seo.meta_description_en: The Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Score with CRP (ASDAS-CRP) describes severity of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) using clinical and laboratory data, specifically CRP.
seo.keywords_en: Ankylosing spondylitis, disease activity score, AS, ASDAS, CRP, RA, rheumatoid arthritis, disease activity index, DAS28, DAS28-CRP

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: Other than CRP, all values are self-reported by the patient and therefore subjective.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• The ASDAS-CRP is the preferred disease activity index according to the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS).

  • May be useful for trending disease activity over time.

next_steps.advice_en: May be useful in helping to guide treatment decisions; e.g. detecting improvement with TNF inhibitors.

about.formula_en:
ASDAS-CRP = (0.12 x back pain) + (0.06 x morning stiffness) + (0.11 x patient global assessment of disease activity) + (0.07 x peripheral pain/swelling) + (0.58 x ln(CRP + 1))

Where variables are:

Back pain

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of AS neck, back, or hip pain you have had?"

Morning stiffness

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of morning stiffness you have had from the time you wake up?"

Patient global assessment of disease activity

Ask the patient: "How active was your spondylitis, on average, during the last week?"

Peripheral pain/swelling

Ask the patient: "How would you describe the overall level of pain/swelling in joints other than neck, back, or hips you have had?"

CRP

C-reactive protein, mg/L

All variables, except CRP, should be graded on a scale of 0 (least severe) to 10 (most severe).

Arthritis Care Res (Hoboken). 2011;63 Suppl 11:S47-58.

creator_info.about_en: Cédric Lukas, MD, PhD, is an associate professor of rheumatology at University Hospital Lapeyronie in Montpellier, France. He is a member of the EULAR Research Center in Montpellier. Dr. Lukas’ primary research is focused on autoimmune disease, inflammatory disease, and clinical rheumatology.
